message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Particles of this size are likely to be trapped by the mucociliary escalator, which is responsible for clearing foreign particles from the respiratory tract. Nasal vibrissae are responsible for trapping larger particles, while phagocytosis by alveolar macrophages and diffusion into pulmonary capillaries are not primary routes of clearance for inhaled particles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The 6.7-μm sized particles are too large to be trapped by nasal vibrissae or diffused into pulmonary capillaries. Alveolar macrophages can phagocytize smaller particles, but 6.7-μm particles are too large for them as well. Therefore, the most likely route of clearance is expulsion by the mucociliary escalator, as particles in the 5-10 μm range are typically cleared by this mechanism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The size of the particles suggests that they will likely be trapped in the upper respiratory tract, but they may also reach the alveoli. The most likely route of clearance for particulate matter in the respiratory system is through the mucociliary escalator, which moves mucus and trapped particles upward and out of the respiratory system.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The size of the particles suggests that they will be trapped in the respiratory bronchioles and alveoli, and then cleared by the mucociliary escalator. Option C is also a possibility, but it is less likely since alveolar macrophages are more effective at clearing particles larger than 10 μm. Option A is less likely since the particles are too large to be trapped by nasal vibrissae. Option D is also less likely since the particles are too large to diffuse into pulmonary capillaries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The particle size of 6.7-μm suggests it will not easily be trapped by nasal vibrissae or diffuse into pulmonary capillaries. It's likely to be cleared by the mucociliary escalator, which sweeps particles toward the pharynx, where they can be coughed up or swallowed. Phagocytosis by alveolar macrophages is also a possible route of clearance, but it's less likely to be the most likely route for particles of this size.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Particulate matter of this size is likely to be trapped in the bronchioles and alveoli, and then cleared by the mucociliary escalator, which moves mucus and foreign particles up and out of the airways. Diffusion into pulmonary capillaries and phagocytosis by alveolar macrophages are not the primary routes of clearance for particulate matter of this size. Trapping by nasal vibrissae is possible for larger particles, but 6.7-μm sized particles are likely to bypass nasal filtration and reach the lower airways.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The size of the particles (6.7 μm) suggests that they are within the range that can be trapped by the mucociliary escalator. Trapping by nasal vibrissae is more likely for larger particles. Phagocytosis by alveolar macrophages is more likely for smaller particles. Diffusion into pulmonary capillaries is not a route of clearance for particulate matter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The size of particles (6.7-μm) suggests that they are in the range of respirable particles and can be cleared by the mucociliary escalator, which moves particles out of the respiratory tract by coordinated action of cilia in the respiratory epithelium. Trapping by nasal vibrissae mostly occurs for larger particles, phagocytosis by alveolar macrophages occurs for smaller particles, and diffusion into pulmonary capillaries occurs for gases, not particles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The aerosol containing 6.7-μm sized particles is most likely to be expelled from the lungs by the mucociliary escalator, which is responsible for removing foreign particles from the lungs. Trapping by nasal vibrissae occurs in larger particles, phagocytosis by alveolar macrophages occurs in smaller particles, and diffusion into pulmonary capillaries does not involve clearance of particulate matter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The size of the particles suggests that they will deposit in the lower respiratory tract. The most likely route of clearance is expulsion by the mucociliary escalator, which is responsible for removing foreign particles and debris from the respiratory tract. Trapping by nasal vibrissae occurs in larger particles, while phagocytosis by alveolar macrophages and diffusion into pulmonary capillaries occur in smaller particles.
